title: ChoiceRank: Identifying Preferences from Node Traffic in Networks
abstract: Understanding how users navigate in a network is of high interest in many applications. We consider a setting where only aggregate node-level traffic is observed and tackle the task of learning edge transition probabilities. We cast it as a preference learning problem, and we study a model where choices follow Luce's axiom. In this case, the $O(n)$ marginal counts of node visits are a sufficient statistic for the $O(n^2)$ transition probabilities. We show how to make the inference problem well-posed regardless of the network's structure, and we present ChoiceRank, an iterative algorithm that scales to networks that contains billions of nodes and edges. We apply the model to a month-long clickstream of the English Wikipedia and one year of rides on New York City's bicycle-sharing system. In both cases, we successfully recover the transition probabilities using only the network structure and marginal (node-level) traffic data.
